node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

node.title: Crypto: will the bitcoin dream succeed?

Jair Bolsonaro’s actions do not just threaten Brazilian democracy—they have also endangered one of the world’s most important natural resources. 

So why are the right-wing president’s followers still so faithful?

Credit: Alamy

In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.text: Myanmar is on the brink of collapse. Its armed forces are continuing a brutal crackdown—arresting, torturing and killing protesters—as Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s de-facto leader, is detained. Our experts answer your questions. Cover image: STR/ Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Leaders Does America face a slowdown in economic growth? Û its biggest economic Delta variant is'.

node.text:
The Delta variant is by far the biggest threat to America's economy. ⁠
⁠
As the ultra-infectious viral variant spreads through the country, covid-19 cases are likely to rocket upwards. ⁠
⁠
The economic consequences of this will depend on how policymakers and consumers react. ⁠
⁠
For the economic recovery to continue, people must be willing to mix with others. Yet that is precisely what Delta puts in jeopardy—even if vaccines eliminate the need to return to strict measures, consumers may become too anxious to visit bars and restaurants. ⁠
⁠
To learn why the risk from the Delta variant is more troubling than the other issues facing America’s recovery, tap the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Who will succeed Angela Merkel? Germany, voting intention in federal election, % Individual polls Average with 95% confidence interval "Emergency brake" lockdown July 23rd Election day 40 30 CDU/CSU 20 Green SPD FDP AfD Left S 10 2020 5 M A 2021 S Sources: Wahlrecht.de; The Economist The Economist'.

node.text:
In September Germany will decide the identity of Angela Merkel's successor. ⁠
⁠
Since 1961 no single party has won a simple majority of seats in the Bundestag, Germany’s lower house of parliament. ⁠
⁠
The country has been led by a “grand” coalition of the Christian Democrats and the Social Democrats for three-quarters of Mrs Merkel’s 16 years in office.⁠
⁠
As the two major parties' share of the vote has fallen in recent years, it is possible that the next government could consist of three parties.⁠
⁠
We're keeping tabs on the runners, the riders and on possible coalitions that will emerge after Germany's federal election. To get up to speed with the latest polling data, click on the link in our bio. #BTW21

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 23, 2021. May be an image of dessert and indoor.

node.text:
The morals of Ben & Jerry’s may be hard to melt. ⁠
⁠
This week the American ice-cream maker announced that it would stop selling its products in Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank from the end of 2022. ⁠
⁠
Such sales, it said, were “inconsistent with [its] values”. Ben & Jerry’s has previously curtailed sales to Hong Kong, Morocco and Russia over human-rights concerns.⁠
⁠
The decision has caused outrage in Israel. Naftali Bennett, the prime minister, called the ban “anti-Israeli” and tried to elicit promises that distribution would not end. ⁠
⁠
But Unilever, the firm’s parent company, allows Ben & Jerry’s independence over its business decisions. ⁠
⁠
Take five minutes to catch up on this and other essential news from today. Click on the link in our bio to read our daily briefing.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Ronen Zvulun/File Photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Earlier this month wildfires tore through the drought-stricken American West. An estimated 78 large fires are raging across 13 states.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The largest of them, the Bootleg Fire in southern Oregon, now takes up almost 395,000 hectares—more than the city of Los Angeles.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Meanwhile, heavy rain caused severe floods in Europe and China. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
At least 199 people in Europe have died and hundreds more are still missing. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Henan, in central China, suffered its heaviest rainfall in a thousand years. Dozens of rivers burst their banks and streets flooded. Tens of thousands of people were displaced.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
You can swipe through this slideshow of images to see the impact of these climate-related disasters. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
After that, click the link in our bio to read why no one is completely safe from the havoc wreaked by a changing climate.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Image credits:⁠⁠
1) Jungho Kim/eyevine⁠⁠
2) Reuters⁠⁠
3) Ty O'Neil/Sipa USA⁠⁠
4) Ty O'Neil/Sipa USA⁠⁠
5) Ty O'Neil/Getty Images⁠⁠
6) ChinaImages/Sipa USA⁠⁠
7) Boris Roessler/Alamy Live News⁠⁠
8) Valentin Bianchi/AP Photo⁠⁠
9) Thilo Schmuelgen/Reuters⁠⁠
10) Francis Mascarenhas/Reuters⁠⁠

node.text:
Hachimura Rui, who has a Japanese mother and a Beninese father, has been chosen to carry the flag for Team Japan at the Olympics. ⁠
⁠
That irks some on the right in Japan, where the idea of racial homogeneity has long held sway. ⁠
⁠
But the image of Japan as a racially homogeneous country has always been a myth. ⁠
⁠
These days it is becoming harder to sustain. At least 10% of 20­-somethings in Tokyo are foreign-­born. There are more foreigners in Japan than at any time in its post-­war history.⁠
⁠
Mr Hachimura is part of a cohort of prominent mixed­-race athletes who are forcing the country to reckon with its racial diversity. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how these athletes make Japan's diversity impossible to ignore.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @elenaxausa

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Asia The 2020 Olympics will 2020 be memorable, but not in the way Japan hoped အာ'.

node.text:
The Tokyo games were shaping up to be a source of pride. But deserted stadiums and covid scares will not rally the nation. ⁠
⁠
Already, there has been a covid-19 outbreak in the Olympic Village and the organisers of the bedevilled games have had to sack Kobayashi Kentaro, the show director of the opening ceremony.⁠
⁠
Rather than coming together for the Olympics, Japan has been divided by them.⁠
⁠
Many fume that the interests of sponsors, TV networks and the IOC seem more important than those of the Japanese people. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why, even if the summer games are successful, a sense of national renewal will remain elusive. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Philip Fong / AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Science & technology A new, green air-con system manages without nasty gases'.

node.text:
Soon it could be possible to cool your house down, without damaging the planet.⁠
⁠
Most air conditioners use refrigerants called hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), potent greenhouse-gases which are hundreds of times more effective at trapping heat in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide is. ⁠
⁠
Exergyn, a Dublin based company, has developed a new type of air conditioning which avoids these polluting HFCs and has few moving parts at its core.⁠
⁠
As well as being more environmentally friendly, the air-conditioning system will also be less expensive to buy and 30-40% cheaper to run.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how the system works, and what other products the green technology could serve.⁠
⁠
Credit: Eric Lafforgue/Getty Images

node.text:
“The pandemic shut down much of the world’s ability to effectively collect samples from athletes.” Oliver Catlin, a leading expert on drugs in sport, explains why doping may have a particularly damaging impact on the Tokyo Olympics, on our “Babbage” podcast.⁠
⁠
Host Tim Cross, The Economist’s Technology editor, investigates the prevalence of doping in sport, and asks if testing can ever keep a lid on the use of performance-enhancing drugs. ⁠
⁠
Also, Sharron Davies, a British swimmer and Olympic silver medallist, tells us about the incredible performance-enhancing effects that doping had on her East German competitors at the 1980 Olympics in Moscow.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to listen to the latest episode of “Babbage”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 22, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'Middle East & Africa South Africa is on the brink. Where does it go from here?'.

node.text:
“This is as close to a rebellion against inequality as South Africa has ever come.”⁠
⁠
After a week of unprecedented violence, the country is on the brink. The effects of the destruction will be felt for years. ⁠
⁠
The failure of the African National Congress (ANC) to build a properly functioning state and to deliver economic growth created the potential for chaos. Lockdowns have pushed South Africans deeper into poverty. Unemployment is at a record high. Millions are going hungry. ⁠
⁠
In 1994 the world watched as South Africans queued from dawn to vote in the country’s ﬁrst fully democratic election. Today the queues are for food, petrol and medicine.⁠
⁠
How did it come to this and where does South Africa go from here? Tap the link in our bio to learn how today's unrest could shape the country's political and economic future.⁠
⁠
Credit: KIM LUDBROOK/EPA-EFE/Shutterstock

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Economist Delta's beta: how much worseto come? Where South Africa goes next Chinese American antitrust The ethics primate research JULY24TH-30TH2021 No safe place The The3 future'.

node.text:
Scenes of destruction have played out around the world over the past weeks. Nowhere is completely safe.⁠
⁠
The ground under the German town of Erftstadt was torn apart like tissue paper by flood waters.⁠
⁠
Lytton in British Columbia was burned from the map just a day after setting a freakishly high temperature record.⁠
⁠
Cars floated like dead ﬁsh through the streets-turned-canals in the Chinese city of Zhengzhou. ⁠
⁠
All the world feels at risk, and most of it is. Greenhouse-gas emissions have produced a planet more than 1°C warmer than pre-industrial days. Imagine if, as is quite possible, temperatures rose by 3°C.⁠
⁠
Cutting emissions is not enough. To read why the world urgently needs to invest in adapting to the changing climate, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Cover: @tylercomrie

node.text:
Unusual times call for unusual measures for a graduation during the covid-19 pandemic. ⁠
⁠
At the Senator Renato Cayetano Memorial Science and Technology High School in Taguig, in the Philippines, graduating students who were self-isolating were represented on the dais by robot stand-ins.⁠
⁠
South-East Asia is in the grip of a surge in covid-19 cases and deaths. ⁠
⁠
If you're interested in science stories such as this, sign up to "Simply Science", our free weekly newsletter. ⁠
⁠
This week's newsletter focused on the increasingly stark consequences of climate change, how floating wind turbines could be the way forward. As well as, fool's gold and the billionaire space race. ⁠
⁠
Head to the link in our bio to sign up. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Dante Diosina Jr/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
